choices.text: RFLP result from a single base change
Single nucleotide change results in change of Glutamate to Valine
HbS confers resistance against malaria in heterozygotes
‘Sticky patch’ is generated as a result of replacement of a nonpolar residue with a polar residue in Sickle Cell Anemia (HbS)

questions.text: A 3.5-year-old girl of Arabian descent presents to the clinic with severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis, and elevated ESR. The history provided by her parents includes fever, cough, pallor, weakness, and tachypnea. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. Following diagnostic evaluations, sickle cell anemia (SCA) is diagnosed. Based on the information provided, which of the following statements about SCA is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ‘Sticky patch’ is generated as a result of replacement of a nonpolar residue with a polar residue in Sickle Cell Anemia (HbS) — this is False.

 

Explanation:

 

In sickle cell anemia, the amino acid substitution involves replacing a polar residue Glutamate with a nonpolar residue (valine) at the 6th position of the β-globin chain.

This substitution creates a hydrophobic “sticky patch” on the surface of the deoxygenated hemoglobin S (HbS) molecule. These hydrophobic patches interact abnormally with each other, leading to polymerization of HbS inside red cells, which causes the characteristic "sickling" shape of RBCs under hypoxic conditions.

So the false statement is that the “sticky patch” arises from a nonpolar → polar substitution — the reality is the opposite:
→ It’s a polar (glutamate) → nonpolar (valine) substitution.

 

 

Other Options:

  • Option A) RFLP result from a single base change:
    Correct — The sickle cell mutation involves a single nucleotide change (A → T at the 6th codon), which eliminates a restriction enzyme site. This difference can be detected using Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) analysis.
  • Option B) Single nucleotide change results in change of Glutamate to Valine:
    Correction: this statement is Correct.
  • Option C) HbS confers resistance against malaria in heterozygotes:
    Correct — Heterozygotes for the HbS gene (sickle cell trait) are relatively protected against Plasmodium falciparum malaria, explaining its evolutionary persistence in malaria-endemic regions.

     

Educational Objective:


In Sickle Cell Anemia (SCA), a single point mutation (A → T) at the 6th codon of the β-globin gene results in the substitution of Glutamate (polar) with valine (nonpolar). This creates a hydrophobic site ("sticky patch") on deoxygenated HbS, triggering polymerization, red cell sickling, hemolysis, and vaso-occlusive complications.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 417, 693.

choices.text: Bilirubin UDP-glucuronosyltransferase
Ferrochelatase
Heme oxygenase
δ-Aminolevulinic acid synthase

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child presents to the pediatric outpatient department with a history of recurrent gastrointestinal disturbances and lethargy over the past few weeks. Laboratory investigations reveal a microcytic, hypochromic anemia and elevated blood lead levels, suggestive of lead poisoning. Given this child's condition, which of the following enzymes would likely exhibit increased activity in the liver as a compensatory or pathophysiological response?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) δ -Aminolevulinic acid synthase

 

Option D:

 

  • This child is a case of acquired porphyria due to lead poisoning, as lead inhibits δ -aminolevulinic acid dehydratase and thereby heme synthesis.
  • So, the decrease in heme levels has 2 effects (i) derepresses δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase -1 (hepatic isozyme) → increase in its activity (ii) decreases the hemoglobin synthesis and results in anemia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Bilirubin UDP-glucuronosyltransferase: This enzyme is involved in the conjugation of bilirubin, not directly affected in lead poisoning.

 

Option B: Ferrochelatase: Lead poisoning actually inhibits ferrochelatase, decreasing its activity. Ferrochelatase catalyzes the insertion of iron into protoporphyrin IX to form heme.

 

Option C: Heme oxygenase: This enzyme catalyzes the degradation of heme to biliverdin, free iron, and carbon monoxide. It is not specifically upregulated in lead poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The effects of lead poisoning on the heme biosynthesis pathway, particularly the inhibition of specific enzymes like ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase, leading to a compensatory increase in δ-ALAS activity.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 326-327, 334.

choices.text: Electrophoretically HbS moves faster than HbA at alkaline pH
Structural difference is related to β-chain
HbS is more prone to polymerization under low oxygen conditions
Lack of negative charge of glutamic acid is attributed to the electrophoretic movement

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is incorrect regarding hemoglobin A (HbA) and hemoglobin S (HbS).
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Electrophoretically HbS moves faster than HbA at alkaline pH

 

Explanation:

 

This statement is false because at alkaline pH (typically ~8.6) during electrophoresis, HbS moves slower than HbA.

 

The reason lies in the structural difference:

  • In Hemoglobin A (HbA), the 6th amino acid of the β-globin chain is glutamic acid, a negatively charged residue at physiological and alkaline pH.
  • In Hemoglobin S (HbS), the same position is occupied by valine, which is neutral.

 

This substitution reduces the overall negative charge of HbS compared to HbA, which leads to slower migration toward the anode (positive pole) during electrophoresis at alkaline pH.

 

 

Other Options:

  • Option B) The structural difference is related to the β-chain:
    Correct — The mutation responsible for HbS is a single point mutation in the β-globin gene. Valine replaces glutamic acid at position 6 of the β-chain.
  • Option C. HbS is more prone to polymerization under low oxygen conditions:
    Correct — Deoxygenated HbS tends to polymerize, causing red blood cells to assume a sickle shape.
  • Option D) Lack of negative charge of glutamic acid is attributed to the electrophoretic movement:
    Correct — The substitution eliminates the negative charge of glutamic acid, reducing the net negative charge of HbS, which slows down its migration on electrophoresis at alkaline pH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sickle cell anemia, the substitution of valine for glutamic acid in the β-globin chain leads to the formation of HbS. This mutation decreases the negative charge of the hemoglobin molecule, causing it to migrate more slowly than HbA during electrophoresis at alkaline pH.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 292.

choices.text: It has 2 alpha and 2 epsilon chains
Electrophoretically moves faster than HbA, under alkaline conditions
It can strongly bind with 2, 3 BPG
It has high affinity for oxygen

questions.text: A 14-week pregnant woman visits her obstetrician for a routine check-up. This is her first pregnancy, and she expresses concerns about a blood disease prevalent in her family. Her laboratory results reveal a low hemoglobin level characterized by a hypochromic, microcytic anemia. Hemoglobin electrophoresis indicates an increased level of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), a finding consistent with α-thalassemia minor. Which of the following is true regarding the structure or function of HbF?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It has a high affinity for oxygen.

 

Option D:

 

  • HbF has 2 alpha chains and 2 gamma chains.


The differences in physicochemical properties when compared with HbA are:

 

  1. Increased solubility of deoxy HbF
  2. Slower electrophoretic mobility for HbF
  3. Increased resistance of HbF to alkali denaturation
  4. HbF has decreased interaction with 2, 3-BPG.
     

 

  • The ODC of foetus and new-born are shifted to the left due to increase in O2 affinity in facilitating transplacental oxygen transport and diminished binding of 2,3-BPG to HbF. When pO2 is 20 mm Hg, the HbF is 50% saturated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: It has 2 alpha and 2 epsilon chains: Has 2 alpha chains and 2 gamma chains.

 

Option B: Electrophoretically moves faster than HbA, under alkaline conditions: Slower electrophoretic mobility for HbF.

 

Option C: It can strongly bind with 2, 3 BPG: Diminished binding of 2,3-BPG

 

Educational Objective:

 

The structural and functional differences between fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and adult hemoglobin (HbA), with a focus on HbF's higher oxygen affinity due to its reduced interaction with 2, 3-bisphosphoglycerate (2, 3-BPG). This characteristic is essential for efficient oxygen transfer from the maternal to the fetal circulation.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/ed: p 293, Harper30/e: p 57.

choices.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is wrong but R is a right statement
A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
Assertion (A): ALA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme of HEME synthesis, regulated allosterically.

 

Reasoning (R): If there is excess of free heme, Fe++ is oxidized to Fe+++ forming hematin, which in turn regulates the enzyme.

 

Assess the statements.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A as well as R are right, and R is a Correct explanation of A.                                                                       

 

Option C:

 

Explanation:

 

  • ALA synthase is regulated by a repression mechanism: Heme inhibits the synthesis of ALA synthase by acting as a co-repressor.
  • ALA synthase is also allosterically inhibited by hematin: When there is excess of free heme, the Fe++ is oxidized to Fe+++ (ferric), thus forming hematin.
  • Also regulated by compartmentalization of the enzymes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ALA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the heme synthesis pathway and its activity is regulated.
  • The feedback inhibition mechanism of heme synthesis where excess heme (and the formation of hematin) directly inhibits ALA synthase, thereby reducing the synthesis of more heme and maintaining homeostasis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 272-273.

choices.text: Inhibition of iron transport
Reduction of heme synthesis
Inhibition of the phosphatidylinositol cycle
Blockage of reticulocyte DNA synthesis

questions.text: The parents of a 6-year-old boy seek medical attention for their son's mental retardation. Laboratory tests reveal microcytic anemia with basophilic stippling of red blood cells. A thorough history reveals that the child has been eating paint chips from the radiators in their old apartment. What is the most likely cause of the boy's anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduction of heme synthesis

 

Option B:

 

  • The boy is suffering from lead poisoning, which he obtained from eating the flaking paint chips. Lead inhibits the δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase step of heme synthesis, leading to reduced heme levels.
  • In addition, the Ferrochelatase step (in which iron is inserted into the newly synthesized heme ring) is also inhibited by lead.
  • The reduced heme levels reduce the amount of functional haemoglobin synthesized, leading to the microcytic anemia observed in the child.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Inhibition of iron transport: While lead can interfere with iron metabolism, the specific findings of basophilic stippling and the context of paint chip consumption point more directly to disrupted heme synthesis rather than iron transport.

 

Option C: Inhibition of the phosphatidylinositol cycle: This is not a recognized mechanism by which lead causes anemia. The phosphatidylinositol cycle is more relevant to signal transduction processes.

 

Option D: Blockage of reticulocyte DNA synthesis: Lead poisoning can affect nucleic acid metabolism, but the basophilic stippling and microcytic anemia are more characteristic of heme synthesis disruption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead poisoning is known to cause microcytic anemia with basophilic stippling. One of the mechanisms by which lead poisoning causes anemia is by inhibiting several key enzymes involved in the heme synthesis pathway, including ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 273.

choices.text: Hyperbolic
Sigmoidal
Exponential
Linear

questions.text: A 45-year-old marathon runner is admitted to the hospital after collapsing during a race. He is found to have rhabdomyolysis secondary to exertional muscle damage. Laboratory investigations are underway to understand the oxygen-binding properties of muscle proteins, particularly myoglobin, in this context. Which of the following best describes the oxygen dissociation curve (ODC) of myoglobin?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperbolic

 

Option A:

 

Myoglobin is an oxygen-binding protein found in muscle tissue. It has a high affinity for oxygen and serves as an oxygen reserve that can be rapidly mobilized during muscle activity. The oxygen dissociation curve (ODC) of myoglobin is hyperbolic, which reflects its relatively simple binding behavior with oxygen; it binds oxygen cooperatively but does not exhibit the same level of cooperative binding as hemoglobin, which has a sigmoidal ODC. The hyperbolic shape indicates that myoglobin's affinity for oxygen remains relatively constant over a wide range of oxygen concentrations, enabling efficient oxygen uptake in the lungs and release in the muscles, even at high oxygen levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Sigmoidal: This describes the ODC of hemoglobin, not myoglobin. Hemoglobin's sigmoidal ODC is due to its cooperative binding of oxygen, where the binding of one oxygen molecule increases the affinity for the next.

 

Option C: Exponential: There is no standard exponential ODC for biological oxygen-binding proteins. This option does not accurately describe the binding behavior of myoglobin or hemoglobin.

 

Option D: Linear: A linear ODC would imply a direct proportionality between oxygen concentration and binding, which does not accurately reflect the binding properties of myoglobin or other biological oxygen-binding proteins.

 

Educational Objective:
 

MYOGLOBIN

 

  • Seen in Muscle and is a Monomer with MW is 17000 KDa
  • Oxygen is stored in red muscle myoglobin and is released during severe exercise for use in muscle mitochondria for aerobic synthesis of ATP.
  • It is rich in alpha helix
  • Bind only one mol of Oxygen and has high affinity for Oxygen than Hb.
  • Exhibit no Bohr effect and no Cooperativity and no interaction with 2, 3 BPG.
  • ODC is Hyperbolic.

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 295.

choices.text: Cytochrome oxidase
Tryptophan pyrrolase
Catalase
Transferrin

questions.text: Which of the following proteins does not contain a heme group?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transferrin

 

Option D:

 

Transferrin is an iron-binding blood plasma glycoprotein that controls the level of free iron in biological fluids. Unlike the other options listed, transferrin does not contain a heme group. Instead, it plays a crucial role in iron transport and homeostasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cytochrome oxidase: Incorrect because cytochrome oxidase is a heme-containing enzyme that is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria, playing a critical role in cellular respiration.

 

Option B. Tryptophan pyrrolase: Incorrect as tryptophan pyrrolase (also known as tryptophan 2,3-dioxygenase) is a heme-containing enzyme involved in the catabolism of tryptophan.

 

Option C. Catalase: Incorrect because catalase, an enzyme that catalyzes the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen, also contains a heme group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 514.
